word.entryDescription: the act of giving something to somebody and receiving something from them
word.entryExample: The assistant offers an exchange.

word.entryDescription: a student studying at one of their institution's partner institutions
word.entryExample: Pilar is an exchange student from Seville and she is enjoying her time here in Cambridge.

word.entryDescription: to be looking forward to something or doing something
word.entryExample: Harry is excited about the party.

word.entryDescription: something that is exciting makes you feel very interested or is full of action
word.entryExample: Watching TV is more exciting than listening to the radio.

word.entryDescription: a reason given to explain why you have done something bad
word.entryExample: What's your excuse, why are you so late?

word.entryDescription: physical activity often done for pleasure or to keep you fit
word.entryExample: Astronauts have to do a lot of exercise.

word.entryDescription: to do physical activity for pleasure or to keep fit
word.entryExample: Try to exercise every day to keep fit.

word.entryDescription: a small book with empty pages that students use to write in
word.entryExample: Write the answer in your exercise book.

word.entryDescription: the progressive form of 'exercise' – to do physical activity for pleasure or to keep fit
word.entryExample: Drinking water is good for you when exercising a lot.

word.entryDescription: waste gases or steam produced by a vehicle
word.entryExample: Car exhaust fumes can pollute the air.

word.entryDescription: extremely tired, especially after doing something
word.entryExample: I was so exhausted and furious that I stayed awake for the whole night.

word.entryDescription: extremely tiring
word.entryExample: After an extremely exhausting journey, the swallow finally gets to South Africa.

word.entryDescription: a feeling of being very tired, with no energy
word.entryExample: It is a very hot day and we can see the exhaustion setting in on their faces.

word.entryDescription: an event where a number of objects is shown to the public
word.entryExample: It will be possible to visit the exhibition tomorrow.

word.entryDescription: the part of a building or an area where people go out
word.entryExample: Take the second exit on your left.

word.entryDescription: unusual and exciting because of being foreign
word.entryExample: Knowing how to look after exotic animals is very important.

word.entryDescription: to increase the capacity of an electronic device
word.entryExample: I need to expand the memory in my PC because it's running very slowly.

word.entryDescription: an amount of money that you spend to buy or do something
word.entryExample: My employer covers all my travelling expenses.

word.entryDescription: costing a lot of money
word.entryExample: A CD is more expensive than a book.

word.entryDescription: knowledge or skills that you get from things that have happened
word.entryExample: What sort of work experience do you have?

word.entryDescription: to have an experience in doing a particular thing
word.entryExample: I'm quite experienced in applying for different jobs. I've been doing it for a few months.

word.entryDescription: a test carried out to see what happens under certain conditions, or to find out if an idea is true
word.entryExample: The children in the experiment were put into two different groups.

word.entryDescription: to travel around a place to find out about it
word.entryExample: Why is Steve so keen to explore space?

word.entryDescription: a very important goal that needs to be achieved
word.entryExample: It is our express aim to continuously improve customer service despite escalating costs and government cutbacks.

word.entryDescription: a look on someone's face that shows the person's feelings or thoughts
word.entryExample: What does the expression on your face mean? Should I be happy or scared?

word.entryDescription: (of a face) not showing any emotion
word.entryExample: His face was expressionless.

word.entryDescription: the progressive form of 'extend' – to continue for a particular distance or time
word.entryExample: We travelled through an area extending from the Red Sea to the Alps.

word.entryDescription: no longer existing
word.entryExample: These animals are extinct now.

word.entryDescription: the process of becoming extinct
word.entryExample: Deforestation causes extinction of wildlife species.

word.entryDescription: to remove something from somewhere or something
word.entryExample: If he wants to have his tooth extracted, he should go to the dentist's.

word.entryDescription: much more severe or serious than usual
word.entryExample: Have you ever experienced any of these kinds of extreme weather?

word.entryDescription: sport that is considered dangerous and exciting, such as skydiving and rock climbing
word.entryExample: What kind of people like extreme sports?

word.entryDescription: to a very high degree
word.entryExample: In extremely cold climates and at high altitudes, glaciers are melting too quickly, and ice floes are breaking up.

word.entryDescription: somebody who is confident, energetic and likes being with other people
word.entryExample: She is fiery and extrovert and lives an impetuous and carefree life.

word.entryDescription: a part of the body on your head that you use for seeing
word.entryExample: My sister has got green eyes.

word.entryDescription: the ability to see
word.entryExample: My granddad's eyesight needs testing.

word.entryDescription: cloth used for making clothes or curtains
word.entryExample: Swathes of fabric are folded and tucked with bows, ties and sashes as finishing touches.

word.entryDescription: the front of your head where your eyes, nose and mouth are
word.entryExample: She has a round face and brown eyes.

word.entryDescription: involving two people who are meeting and talking directly to each other
word.entryExample: Can I talk to you face-to-face in my office?

word.entryDescription: relating to the face
word.entryExample: Facial recognition helps us know our enemies.

word.entryDescription: (plural 'facilities') a building or room provided for a particular purpose
word.entryExample: Yes, we have all the facilities. Toilets, hot showers, a shop, an adventure playground and even wi-fi!

word.entryDescription: a piece of true information or a thing that happened
word.entryExample: Harry likes the fact the activities are cool.

word.entryDescription: a large building in which they make things
word.entryExample: Do you know where the factory is?

word.entryDescription: to become less bright and slowly disappear or to gradually become less loud
word.entryExample: It was a beautiful, faded, ex-colonial building with dark wooden floors and a sharp smell of varnish and coffee.

word.entryDescription: to be unsuccessful in a test or exam
word.entryExample: And if I fail my exams, I won't get into the unit where I want to study.

word.entryDescription: a message that pops up on a screen when the system has failed to process a request
word.entryExample: When I sent my report to print, a failure message came up on screen.

word.entryDescription: lacking confidence or courage
word.entryExample: The High Rocks cave tours are not for the faint-hearted.

word.entryDescription: a movement that promotes buying from companies that pay workers fairly
word.entryExample: The reporter said that the future of Fairtrade is in the hands of shoppers.

word.entryDescription: to make things that are not real to appear real
word.entryExample: They hoped that he had faked his disappearance to start a new life away from the music business.

word.entryDescription: to drop to the ground or a lower position, usually without control
word.entryExample: The baby in China had a fall from the 10th floor of a building.
